th.p: Minimum volume of extinguishing stream (litres per minute)

content.p: Every person who develops or redevelops a township must ensure that fire hydrants are plotted on a plan and installed in accordance with the following minimum delivery volumes and distance frequencies:

td.p: Minimum fire hydrant delivery volume measured at peak consumption (litres per minute)

content.p: Every person who develops or redevelops a township must ensure that the position of fire hydrants are plotted accurately on a plan that is furnished to the Chief Fire Officer for operational fire-fighting purposes.

blockList.listIntroduction: For purposes of sections 26 and 27, the following areas of a township must be regarded –
as high risk –

item.p: any factory area, high density shopping area, warehouse or commercial building;
any plantation, timber yard or wooden building;
any building higher than 3 storeys;
any building in which hazardous substances are used, handled or stored or in which hazardous processes are conducted; and
any other area that has a high fire risk or high fire spread risk;

blockList.listIntroduction: as moderate risk -
any area in which –

item.p: factories, commercial buildings or residential buildings are generally detached from each other and do not exceed 3 storeys; and
the Chief Fire Officer has not declared the materials processed or stored in these buildings as highly dangerous;
any area where the fire risk and spread risk of fire is moderate; and
any other area that is not a high or low risk area; and

blockList.listIntroduction: as low risk –

item.p: any area that is mainly residential or semi-rural;
any area that has predominantly detached, duet, cluster or town house developments; and
any area where the fire risk or risk of spread of fire is slight or insignificant.

content.p: No person may obtain a water connection to the water reticulation system of the Council unless the fire protection plans for the premises to be connected have been approved by the Chief Fire Officer.

blockList.listIntroduction: Every person or owner of premises who requires a water connection to the water reticulation system of the Council must -
if the premises to be connected are protected by a sprinkler installation, ensure that –

item.p: the connection is calculated and designed for each sprinkler installation in accordance with a rational design as contemplated in the National Building Regulations and Building Standards Act, and
the size, delivery pressure and flow of the water connection is calculated in advance by the responsible engineer;
if the Chief Fire Officer requires a larger water connection for purposes of fire-fighting, provide the larger water connection;
ensure that the size, work pressure and delivery flow, except in the case of a water connection to a sprinkler installation, is calculated and designed in accordance with SABS 0400 (Part W); and
ensure that the water installation upon completion complies with the provisions of SABS-1:1994.

section.heading: Use of fireworks prohibited in certain circumstances

blockList.listIntroduction: Unless so authorised in terms of section 33, no person may use fireworks –

item.p: within 500 metres of any explosives factory, explosives storage place, petrol depot or petrol station;
inside any building;
on any agricultural holding;
at any public place; or
at any school, old age home or hospital.

content.p: No person may light or ignite fireworks in any place where animals are present.

blockList.listIntroduction: Unless so authorised in terms of section 33, no person may light or ignite fireworks on any day or at any time except

item.p: New Years Eve from 23h00 to 01h00;
New Years Day from 19h00 to 22h00;
Hindu New Year from 19h00 to 22h00;
Lag b’omer from 19h00 to 22h00;
Chinese New Year from 19h00 to 22h00;
Human Rights Day from 19h00 to 22h00;
Freedom Day from 19h00 to 22h00;
Guy Fawkes Day from 19h00 to 22h00;
Divali from 19h00 to 22h00;
Christmas Eve from 19h00 to 22h00; and
Day of Goodwill from 19h00 to 22h00.

content.p: No person may allow any minor under his or her control to use, light or ignite fireworks in contravention of subsection (1), (2) or (3).

blockList.listIntroduction: No person may present a fireworks display unless -

item.p: authorised to do so by the Council as contemplated in section 33; (b) authorised to do so by the Civil Aviation Authority and the Chief Inspector of Explosives;
the display is at all times under that person’s supervision and control;
the Service and a suitably qualified explosives expert from the South African Police Services are at all times in attendance at the display;

blockList.listIntroduction: that person has ensured that -

item.p: an area with a radius of at least 50 metres is clearly demarcated for the launching of fireworks at the display; and
measures are in place to prevent any person who is not involved in the presentation of the display from entering this launching area; and
a pyrotechnist is at all times present and responsible for the use of fireworks at the display.

blockList.listIntroduction: Any person who wishes to present a fireworks display must apply to the Chief Fire Officer for authorisation by completing and submitting an application in the form and manner determined by the Council together with the prescribed fee and the following documentation:

item.p: Proof of permission for the fireworks display from the Civil Aviation Authority;
proof that an application for the fireworks display has been submitted to the Chief Inspector of Explosives;
a letter of consent from the owner or person responsible for the property on which the fireworks display is proposed to be presented; and
a sketch plan of the proposed venue for the fireworks display, including the demarcated area for the launching of the fireworks.

content.p: The application, prescribed fee and accompanying documentation must be submitted to the Chief Fire Officer at least 14 days before the date of the proposed fireworks display.

If the Council decides to approve an application to present a fireworks display, it must provide the applicant with written confirmation of its decision and any conditions that it may impose to safeguard persons and property.
The Council may require that the fireworks display be presented only on suitable premises designated by the Council and under the supervision and control of an official designated by the Council.

blockList.listIntroduction: No person may deal in fireworks unless -

item.p: that person holds the required fireworks licence in terms of the Explosives Act; and
has the written authority of the Chief Fire Officer.

blockList.listIntroduction: Any person who wishes to obtain the written authority of the Chief Fire Officer to deal in fireworks as contemplated in subsection (1)(b), must -

item.p: complete an application in the form and manner determined by the Council; and
submit it to the Chief Fire Officer together with the prescribed fee at least 30 days before the authority is required by the applicant.

content.p: The Chief Fire Officer may cancel any written authority to deal in fireworks if the holder of the authority contravenes or fails to comply with any provision of these By-laws or any other applicable law.

chapter.heading: Certificate of registration for use, handling and storage of flammable substances

section.heading: Use, handling and storage of flammable substances prohibited in certain circumstances

content.p: Subject to the provisions of subsection (3), no person may use, handle or store any flammable substance or allow such substance to be used, handled or stored on any premises unless that person is the holder of a certificate of registration issued by the Chief Fire Officer in respect of the flammable substance and the premises concerned.
A certificate of registration contemplated in subsection (1) is not required if the flammable substance concerned is of any class and does not exceed the quantity stipulated in Schedule 2.

blockList.listIntroduction: No person may use, handle or store any flammable substance in respect of which no certificate of registration is required or allow such substance to be used, handled or stored on any premises, unless the flammable substance -
is used, handled or stored in a manner that ensures that –

item.p: no flammable substance nor any flammable substance fumes come into contact with any source of ignition that may cause the flammable substance or fumes to ignite;
in the event of a fire or other emergency, the escape of any person or animal is not hindered or obstructed in any way; or

blockList.listIntroduction: is used, handled or stored -

item.p: in a naturally ventilated room that prevents the accumulation of fumes or gas;
in a suitable place outdoors that ensures the safe disposal of fumes or gas; or
the flammable substance is stored in strong, gas-tight and labelled containers.

section.heading: Application for certificate of registration for flammable substances

content.p: An application for a certificate of registration contemplated in section 35(1) must be completed and submitted in the form and manner determined by the Council, together with the prescribed fee.

blockList.listIntroduction: If the Chief Fire Officer issues a certificate of registration to any person, that Officer must endorse on the certificate -

item.p: the class and quantity of the flammable substance for which the premises have been registered;
the number of storage tanks or storage facilities on the premises and their capacities;
the number of flammable substance storerooms on the premises and their capacities;
the number of liquified petroleum gas installations, types of installations and the combined capacity of all cylinders that may be stored on the premises;
the number of storage facilities for any other flammable substance and the volume of each such facility;
the period of validity and expiry date of the certificate; and
the physical address of the premises and the name and postal address of the occupant.

blockList.listIntroduction: A certificate of registration -

item.p: is not transferable between premises;
may not be issued by the Chief Fire Officer for a period exceeding 12 months;
may be transferred to the new owner of the premises in respect of which it was issued, only if an application for such transfer is approved by the Chief Fire Officer in writing.

blockList.listIntroduction: A certificate of registration is valid only for -

item.p: the installation for which it was issued;
the state of the premises at the time of issue; and
for the quantities of flammable substance stated on the certificate.

section.heading: Availability of certificate of registration at premises

content.p: The holder of a certificate of registration must ensure that the certificate is available on the premises concerned at all times for inspection by any member of the Service.

blockList.listIntroduction: Any person who holds a certificate of registration or other authorisation contemplated in these By-laws must ensure that the premises to which the authorisation applies, are equipped with –
subject to the provisions of subsection (6), portable fire extinguishers –

item.p: as specified in SABS 1567 (carbon dioxide-type), SABS 810 (dry chemical-type), SABS 1573 (foam-type) and SABS 1571 (transportable-type);
in such numbers as is appropriate in each section of the premises in accordance with the SABS codes applicable to the flammable substance and risk concerned;

blockList.listIntroduction: if applicable, hose reels as specified in SABS 453 (hose reels), that are connected to a water supply –

item.p: as contemplated in SABS 0400 (Part W); and
that enables each hose reel to maintain a minimum flow of 0,5 litres per second at a minimum work pressure of 300 kPa;

blockList.listIntroduction: if applicable, fire hydrants –

item.p: with couplings as specified in SABS 1128 (Part II) (fire-fighting equipment- couplings); and
in a ratio of at 1 to every 1000 square metres or part thereof. and

blockList.listIntroduction: if applicable, in relation to any above-ground facility, a sprinkler system or delute system that –

item.p: is approved by the Chief Fire Officer; and
with the exception of temporary storage facilities, is installed in a position indicated in the building plans for the premises.

blockList.listIntroduction: Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (1), if the Chief Fire Officer believes that there is any exceptional hazard or risk in respect of the premises concerned, he or she may -

item.p: specify the type of fire extinguisher to be installed;
require that a greater number of fire extinguishers be installed; and
require that a fire detection or warning system be installed.

blockList.listIntroduction: The holder of any certificate of registration or other authorisation contemplated in these By-laws must ensure that all fire-fighting equipment contemplated in subsection (1) -
is inspected, maintained and serviced to the satisfaction of the Chief Fire Officer –

item.p: by a competent, registered and appropriately qualified tradesman in accordance with the provisions of SABS 1015 and SABS 1475;
at least every 12 months;
if installed outside the premises, is adequately protected from the weather; and

blockList.listIntroduction: is positioned prominently or where this is not possible, the position of the fire-fighting equipment is clearly indicated by a symbolic safety sign –

item.p: in accordance with the specifications of SABS 1186; and
to the satisfaction of the Chief Fire Officer.

content.p: The Chief Fire Officer may amend any certificate of registration on application by the holder.
The provisions of section 24, read with the necessary changes, apply to any cancellation by the Chief Fire Officer of a certificate of registration.
Any application for the renewal of a certificate of registration must be submitted to the Chief Fire Officer at least 30 days prior to the expiry date of the certificate.

section.heading: No authorisation required for certain motor vehicle fuel tanks

blockList.listIntroduction: No certificate of registration contemplated in section 35 or any other authorisation contemplated in these by-laws is required in respect of flammable liquids in a fuel tank -

item.p: of any motor vehicle; and
of any stationery engine if the volume of the fuel tank does not exceed 1 000 litres.

content.p: The Chief Fire Officer must keep updated records of all premises in respect of which a certificate of registration has been issued, amended or renewed,

chapter.heading: General provisions regarding the use, handling and storage of flammable substances

section.heading: General prohibitions regarding use, handling and storage of flammable substances

blockList.listIntroduction: No person who uses, handles or stores a flammable substance or allows them to be used, handled or stored on any premises may -

item.p: do anything or allow anything to be done that may result in or cause a fire or explosion;
do anything or allow anything to be done that may obstruct the escape to safety of any person or animal during an emergency.

blockList.listIntroduction: No person may –

item.p: dump or spill or allow the dumping or spilling of any flammable substance into any borehole, sewer, drain system or surface water;
discard or allow the discarding of any flammable substance from any premises in any way other than by a competent person who is properly equipped and authorised to do in terms of these By-laws;
make or bring any fire or device capable of producing an open flame or allow any other person to do so, within 5 metres of any place where a flammable substance is stored;

use or allow to be used any device in connection with a flammable substance in any basement level of a building, other than a gas welding or cutting device, used for the sole purpose of maintenance of the building;

blockList.listIntroduction: while any person, except the driver or any other person responsible for a bus contemplated in the National Road Traffic Act, is in or on the bus –

item.p: fill or allow the filling of its fuel tank; or
transport or allow the transport of any flammable substance on the bus, except in its fuel tank; and

deliver or supply or allow to be delivered or supplied, any flammable substance to any premises unless the owner or person in charge of the premises is in possession of a valid certificate of registration.

section.heading: Use, handling and storage of liquefied petroleum gas

blockList.listIntroduction: No person may use, handle or store liquefied petroleum gas in any quantity exceeding that stipulated in Schedule 2 unless –

item.p: the person is in possession of a certificate of registration contemplated in section 35; and
the use, handling and storage of the liquefied petroleum gas complies with the requirements of SABS 087, Parts 1, 3, 7 and 10.

content.p: Liquid petroleum gas may only be used, handled or stored within property boundaries and in compliance with safety distances stipulated in SABS 087, Parts 1, 3, 7 and 10.
Any storage of liquid petroleum gas cylinders at any service station for retail purposes must comply with SABS 087, Part 7.
No liquid petroleum gas cylinder may be used, handled or stored at any public exhibition or demonstration without the prior written permission of the Chief Fire Officer.
An application for permission contemplated in subsection (4) must be made in writing at least 14 days before the event concerned .

The Chief Fire Officer may impose any reasonable condition on the use, handling and storage of liquid petroleum gas cylinders at a public exhibition or demonstration, including but not limited to, the number of cylinders, the manner of storage, safety distances and other safety requirements.
Any person using, handling or storing any liquid petroleum gas cylinder at any public exhibition or demonstration must comply with any condition imposed in terms fo subsection (6).

section.heading: Display of symbolic warning signs required

blockList.listIntroduction: The owner of any premises where any flammable or explosive substance is used, handled or stored must, in the affected area of the premises, display symbolic signs –

item.p: prohibiting smoking and open flames;
of a size and number determined by the Chief Fire Officer; and
prominently in places where the signs can be clearly observed.

content.p: No person may disregard or allow to be disregarded any prohibition on a symbolic sign displayed in terms of subsection (1).

section.heading: Duty to report fires, accidents and dumping

content.p: If any fire, accident or dumping involving a flammable substance has caused damage to any person, animal, property or the environment on any premises, the owner or occupier of the premises must immediately report it to the Chief Fire Officer.

section.heading: Storage of flammable substances prohibited in certain circumstances

blockList.listIntroduction: No person may store or allow the storage of any flammable substance in any storeroom unless –

item.p: that person has a certificate of registration contemplated in section 35; and
the storeroom complies with the requirements of these By-laws and any other applicable law.

section.heading: Symbolic safety signs must be displayed

blockList.listIntroduction: The holder of a certificate of registration for a storeroom to be used for any flammable substance must ensure that-
symbolic safety signs prohibiting open flames and smoking are displayed in the storeroom –

item.p: of a number determined by the Chief Fire Officer;
of dimensions at least 290 millimetres by 200 millimetres; and
manufactured in accordance with SABS 1186;

the groups of flammable substances and their corresponding quantities which may be stored in the storeroom are indicated on the outside of every door to the storeroom in red letters at least 75 millimetres high, against a white background.

blockList.listIntroduction: Every storeroom must be designed and constructed according to the following criteria:

item.p: The storeroom floor must consist of concrete;
the storeroom walls must consist of material that has a fire resistance of at least 120 minutes;

blockList.listIntroduction: the storeroom roof must consist of –

item.p: reinforced concrete with a fire resistance of at least 120 minutes; or

blockList.listIntroduction: any other non-combustible material, if the storeroom -

item.p: boundary of the premises; or
adjoins a higher wall with no opening within 10 metres is not situated within 5 metres of any adjacent building or above and 5 metres on either side of the storeroom.

blockList.listIntroduction: Every storeroom must be equipped with a fire rated fire door that -

item.p: is manufactured and installed in accordance with SABS 1253;
opens to the outside;
is equipped with a lock or locks approved by the Chief Fire Officer; and
is at all times capable of being opened from the inside of the storeroom without the use of a key.

content.p: A storeroom must be equipped with two or more fire doors if the distance to be covered from any part in that storeroom to a door is 4 metres or more, in which case, the fire doors must be installed as far from each other as is practicable in the circumstances.

blockList.listIntroduction: Fire doors contemplated in subsections (1) and (2) must if installed on –

item.p: external walls, be “B” class fire doors; and
internal walls in communication within a building, be “D” class fire doors.

blockList.listIntroduction: Every storeroom window frame must -

item.p: consist of steel;
have window panels of dimensions not exceeding 450 millimetres x 450 millimetres; and
be fitted with wire glass of a thickness not less than 8 millimetres.

content.p: No storeroom window must be capable of being opened.
Every storeroom window must be fitted to the external wall of a building.

blockList.listIntroduction: Every storeroom must be designed and constructed so that its floor is recessed below the level of the door sill to form a catch pit -

item.p: with a holding capacity at least equal to the total volume of hazardous substances capable of being stored in the storeroom, plus 10 percent; and

blockList.listIntroduction: if required by the Chief Fire Officer –

item.p: covered at door sill level by a strong, stable, non-combustible and oxidation free floor grill; and
equipped, at its lowest level, with a non-corrosive drainage valve for cleaning purposes and product recovery.

content.p: The floor grill contemplated in subsection (i) must contain a suitably positioned access hatch for cleaning purposes.

blockList.listIntroduction: Every storeroom must be designed and constructed to ensure -

item.p: the effective ventilation of flammable substance fumes;
that fumes released from the storeroom into the open air will not come into contact with any source of ignition.

blockList.listIntroduction: If the storeroom is designed and constructed for natural ventilation, the owner or person in charge of the storeroom must ventilate the storeroom at a minimum cycle of 30 air changes per hour by installing non-combustible airbricks –

item.p: that are not less than 140 millimetres by 250 millimetres in extent, with non-corrosive gauze wire with a minimum opening diameter of 0.5 millimetres;
that are provided in at least 3 external walls of the storeroom; and
that are positioned 100 millimetres above the level of the sill and 100 millimetres below the level of the roof and not more than 450 millimetres apart.

blockList.listIntroduction: If the storeroom is designed and constructed for mechanical ventilation, the owner or person in charge of the storeroom must equip it with a mechanical ventilation system –

item.p: designed and installed for this purpose;
with a flow rate of 0,5 meters / second across the store;
with vanes that consist of a static-free material;

blockList.listIntroduction: that discharges through a vertical metal duct into the open air –

item.p: not situated within 5 metres of any opening of a building or erf boundary; and
terminating at least 1 metre above roof height or at least 3.6 meters above ground level, whichever is the greater;
equipped with ventilators that are firmly attached to the inside of the walls of the storeroom and, in the case of bottom ventilators, as close as possible to the level of the sill;
with all ventilation or air duct openings in the external wall opposite the mechanical ventilator installed 100 millimetres above the level of the sill to ensure effective cross-ventilation; and

blockList.listIntroduction: equipped with ducting material that –

item.p: is as short as possible in the circumstances and does not have sharp bends; and

is fitted with a fire damper of at least 120 minutes fire resistance at any point where the ducting exits the storeroom, if ducting material is installed external to the storeroom in communication with the remainder of the building.

blockList.listIntroduction: The owner or person in charge of any storeroom must ensure that -

item.p: all electrical apparatus, fittings or switch gear used or installed in the storeroom are used or installed as contemplated in SABS 0108;

blockList.listIntroduction: no switch gear, distribution box, fuse or other electrical equipment, except electrical equipment as contemplated in SABS 0108, is situated –

item.p: inside the storeroom; or
in any position where it may come into contact with any flammable substance fumes leaving the storeroom;
any metal part, electrical fittings and device used in or in connection with the storeroom are earthed effectively to each other and to the ground;
any mechanical ventilation system switch is situated outside the storeroom;
any mechanical ventilation system is on at all times, except when the system is being repaired or replaced, in which case the system must be repaired or replaced without delay; and
all electrical apparatus and fittings, except the mechanical ventilation system, are switched off when the storeroom is unattended.

content.p: Any electrical installation in a storeroom may be installed and certified only by an electrician who is qualified and competent by virtue of his or her training and experience.

The owner or person in charge of a storeroom must submit the certificate contemplated in subsection (2) to the Chief Fire Officer for record purposes immediately after installation contemplated in that subsection.

section.heading: Foam inlets required for certain storerooms

blockList.listIntroduction: The owner or person in charge of a storeroom that is used or intended to be used for storing more than 5000 litres of flammable substance must ensure -

item.p: that the storeroom is provided with a foam inlet consisting of a 65 mm male instantaneous coupling and mild steel pipe work leading to the inside thereof; and
that the foam inlet is identified by a sign in block letters at least 100 millimetres high, displaying the words “foam inlet”.

content.p: The owner or person in charge of a storeroom must ensure that any racking of shelving erected or installed in the storeroom is of non-combustible material.

section.heading: Unauthorised use and entry of storerooms prohibited

blockList.listIntroduction: No person may –

item.p: without the authority of the owner or person in charge, enter or allow any other person to enter any storeroom;
use any storeroom or allow it to be used for any purpose other than for the use, handling or storage of flammable substances;
allow any person to work in a storeroom unless all the doors of the storeroom are wide open or the mechanical ventilation system is switched on; or
place or allow to be placed any obstruction or hindrance in a passage of any storeroom or in front of any storeroom door.

content.p: The owner or person in charge of any premises where quantities of flammable liquids exceeding those stipulated in Schedule 3 are decanted or mixed, must ensure that any room where decanting or mixing takes place complies with all requirements of this Chapter applicable to storerooms.

section.heading: Temporary above ground storage of flammable substances

content.p: Any person who wishes to store any flammable substance on premises on a temporary basis, must apply to the Chief Fire Officer for a temporary certificate of registration.

blockList.listIntroduction: A temporary certificate of registration may be issued by the Chief Fire Officer -

item.p: for a period not exceeding 12 months;

blockList.listIntroduction: if the flammable substance concerned is required -

item.p: in respect of excavation work, construction work or road construction if the volume of the flammable substance does not exceed 9 000 litres;
in respect of small fleet maintenance or research purposes, if the volume of the flammable substance does not exceed 4 400 litres; and
the application complies with the requirements of SABS 0131 and this Chapter.

blockList.listIntroduction: Every holder of a temporary certificate of registration contemplated in subsection (1) must ensure that –

item.p: a storage tank for the flammable substance is not erected within 3.5 metres of any erf boundary, building, excavation, road, driveway or any other flammable substances or combustible material;
adequate provision is made for rainwater run-off from retaining walls or embankments;
no source of ignition or potential source of ignition exists within 5 metres of a storage tank;
a symbolic sign of dimensions at least 300 millimetres by 300 millimetres prohibiting smoking and open flames is displayed on every side of a temporary storage tank; and
at least two 9 kilogram dry chemical fire extinguishers are installed and kept in good working condition, within 10 metres of a temporary storage tank.

section.heading: Hand tools must be intrinsically safe

content.p: The owner or person in charge of any flammable substance storeroom must ensure that any hand tool used in the storeroom is intrinsically safe.

section.heading: Permanent above ground storage tanks for flammable liquids

blockList.listIntroduction: In addition to any other requirement of this Chapter, the owner or person in charge of an above ground storage tank for flammable liquids must ensure –
that the tank is erected or installed –

item.p: in accordance with SABS 0131 and SABS 089, Part I;
at least 3.5 metres from any erf boundary, building, excavation, road, driveway or any other flammable substance, combustible substance or combustible material;
that the flammable liquid stored in the tank must be clearly identified by means of Hazchem placards contemplated in SABS 0232, Part 1.

content.p: Any electrical installation associated with the storage tank must comply with SABS 0108 and SABS 089, Part 2.

section.heading: Underground storage tanks for flammable liquids

content.p: The owner or person in charge of any premises used or intended to be used for the underground storage of any flammable liquid must ensure that any underground storage tank, pump, dispenser and pipe work is erected or installed in accordance with SABS 0400, SABS 089, Part 3 and SABS 0131.

section.heading: Installing, erecting, removing and demolishing prohibited without prior notice

content.p: No person may, in respect of registered premises, erect, install, remove, demolish, extend or change any delivery pump, storage tank, storeroom, spraying room, gas installation, storage facility, fire protection arrangement or floor layout unless that person has given the Chief Fire Officer at least three working days prior written notice of the intention to do so, in the form and manner determined by the Council.
The notice in term of subsection (1) must include the intended commencement date and estimated completion date of the proposed work.

blockList.listIntroduction: The provisions of subsection (1) do not apply to –

item.p: the temporary removal of equipment for purposes of carrying out necessary repairs;
the necessary replacement of equipment or their parts; and
the replacement of any storage tank with a tank of the same capacity.

section.heading: Repair and maintenance of access to storage tanks

blockList.listIntroduction: No person may enter or allow any other person to enter any storage tank that has at any time contained a flammable substance -

item.p: until such tank has been de-aerated and made free of gas and fumes as contemplated in SABS 089 (Part I); or

blockList.listIntroduction: unless that person –

item.p: is wearing an effective self-supporting breathing apparatus; and
is attached to a rescue rope under the control of a competent and responsible person.

section.heading: Termination of storage and use of flammable substances

blockList.listIntroduction: If an aboveground or underground tank installation, liquid petroleum gas installation or associated pipe work is no longer required for the storage or use of a flammable substance, the owner or person in charge of the premises on which the installation is located, must

item.p: notify the Chief Fire Officer in writing within seven days of such storage or use ceasing;
ensure that the flammable substance is removed from the installation and the premises are rendered safe within 30 days of the cessation;
unless the Chief Fire Officer directs otherwise, remove the installation including any associated pipe work from the premises within 180 days of the cessation; and
to the satisfaction of the Council, restore any public foot path or roadway that has been disturbed by the removal of the installation within a period of 7 days of completing such removal.

content.p: Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (1) if the removal of any underground tank installation for the storage of a flammable substance will detrimentally affect the stability of the premises concerned, the owner or person in charge of the installation may, with the prior written permission of the Chief Fire Officer, fill the underground tank with liquid cement slurry.

blockList.listIntroduction: Every flammable substance container must

item.p: be kept closed when not in use;
be declared gas- or vapour-free by a competent person before any modification or repairs are undertaken;
be manufactured and maintained in such condition as to be reasonably safe from damage and to prevent leakage of any flammable substance or vapour from the container.

content.p: Every flammable liquid container must be labelled and marked with words and details indicating the flammable liquid contained in the container as well as any hazard associated with the flammable liquid.
No person may extract flammable liquid from a container of a capacity exceeding 200 litres, unless the container is fitted with an adequately sealed pump or tap.
Any empty flammable liquid container must be stored in a storeroom.

blockList.listIntroduction: Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (4) the Chief Fire Officer may permit the storage of any empty flammable liquid container in the open air if no storeroom is available and if he or she is satisfied that -

item.p: the storage area is in a position and of sufficient size that a fire hazard or other threatening danger will not be caused;
the storage area is well ventilated and enclosed by a wire mesh fence;
the fence supports are of steel or reinforced concrete;
the storage area has an outward opening gate that is kept locked when not in use;

when the floor area exceeds 10 m2 an additional escape gate is installed and fitted with a sliding bolt or other similar locking device that can be opened from the inside without the use of a key; and
the storage area is free of vegetation and has a non-combustible, firm and level base.

content.p: When the quantity of flammable and combustible liquids to be stored is more than 100 litres of class l and/ or more than 210 liters of class ll and class lll A combined, such flammable and combustible liquids must be stored in a store room.

chapter.heading: Transport, supply and delivery of dangerous goods

section.heading: Transport of dangerous goods prohibited without permits

blockList.listIntroduction: The owner of any vehicle used for transporting dangerous goods, must -

item.p: be in possession of a valid transport permit issued by the Chief Fire Officer in accordance with the National Road Traffic Act; and
ensure that the transport permit is available in the vehicle for inspection at all times.

content.p: An application for a transport permit must be completed and submitted to the Chief Fire Officer in the form and manner determined by the Council together with the prescribed fee.

blockList.listIntroduction: A transport permit -

item.p: may not be issued by the Chief Fire Officer for a period longer than 12 months; and

blockList.listIntroduction: must –

item.p: indicate the date of issue and expiry;
identify the issuing officer and bear that officer's signature;
contain a serial number;
indicate the group and quantity of dangerous goods that may be transported under the permit; and
contain a description of the vehicle concerned, including its registration number.

content.p: The provisions of section 24, read with the necessary changes, apply to any cancellation of a transport permit by the Chief Fire Officer.
A transport permit contemplated in section 69 is not required for the transportation of dangerous goods of the type and not exceeding the quantities stipulated in Schedule 3.

section.heading: Design, construction, maintenance and repair of road tankers

blockList.listIntroduction: Every person who designs, constructs, maintains or repairs any road tanker for the transportation of dangerous goods must -

item.p: comply with the provisions of SABS 0189, SABS 1398, SABS 0233, SABS 087, Part 6 SABS 089, Part 1, SABS 0230 and SABS 1518, as the case may be; and
ensure that the road tanker is labelled in a manner that complies with the provisions of SABS 0232 and any applicable law.

section.heading: Design, construction, maintenance and repair of other vehicles

blockList.listIntroduction: Every person who designs, constructs, maintains or repairs any vehicle for the transportation of dangerous goods, except a road tanker, must ensure that the vehicle –
is designed and constructed –

item.p: to safely transport the quantity and type of dangerous goods for which the vehicle is intended to be used; and
with at least two independent axle systems, each with its own suspension system, excluding any trailer forming part of an articulated vehicle;

blockList.listIntroduction: is equipped with –
a safety edge or safety railing

item.p: at least 1 metre high when measured from the surface of the body of the vehicle; and
capable of securing dangerous goods containers;

blockList.listIntroduction: strong and durable straps -

item.p: capable of fastening dangerous goods containers securely to the body of the vehicle;
that are anchored firmly to the bodywork of the vehicle; and
that are fitted with a reversible cog winch mechanism that can be locked;
electrical wiring that complies with SABS 314;
at least 2 static-free wheel blocks;
a power insulating switch, excluding the ignition switch, situated in close proximity to the vehicle battery and in a position readily accessible in any emergency; and
a spark-proof and static-free tank that is designed, constructed and equipped to protect any dangerous goods consignment from shock or ignition while in transit.

section.heading: General prohibitions regarding transport of dangerous goods

blockList.listIntroduction: No person may use or allow to be used, any vehicle to transport dangerous goods, unless –

item.p: the vehicle has a valid roadworthy certificate;

blockList.listIntroduction: if not exempt in terms of section 73, the vehicle is equipped with at least two 9 kilogram dry chemical fire extinguishers -

item.p: designed and manufactured in accordance with SABS 810 and maintained in accordance with SABS 0105 and SABS 1475; and
positioned and installed so that there is at least one fire extinguisher on each side of the vehicle that can be reached quickly and easily in the event of a fire.

content.p: No person may use or allow to be used any vehicle to transport dangerous goods unless the vehicle cabin, body, cargo space, cargo tank, fuel tank, chassis and engine are effectively and permanently earthed with each other.

section.heading: Supply of dangerous goods prohibited in certain circumstances

content.p: No person may deliver or supply or allow to be delivered or supplied any dangerous goods of a type and in a quantity exceeding that specified in Schedule 2 to any premises that are not registered as contemplated in section 35.

No person may deliver or supply or allow to be delivered or supplied any dangerous goods to any premises in contravention of any conditions of the certificate of registration applicable to those premises.
No person may handle or allow to be handled any container containing dangerous goods in a manner that may damage that container.

blockList.listIntroduction: Every person who delivers dangerous goods must ensure that -

item.p: a 9 kilogram dry chemical fire-extinguisher is available at all times during the delivery;
during any transfer of the dangerous goods, the delivery vehicle is physically earthed to the storage facility to which the dangerous goods are being transferred;

blockList.listIntroduction: while delivering –

item.p: the delivery vehicle is placed in such a position that it can be moved easily and quickly in the event of an emergency;
the delivery vehicle is not parked on or across a pavement or a road;
no delivery hose lies on or across a pavement, road or other premises;
no dangerous goods are transferred to a storage facility that does not comply with the requirements of Chapter 6 and the provisions of SABS 0263;

blockList.listIntroduction: any device connected with, or used for, the delivery of the dangerous goods -

item.p: is designed for its purpose; and
is maintained in safe and good working condition; and
no dangerous goods are spilled during delivery.

content.p: No person may transfer or allow to be transferred any dangerous goods to any motor vehicle, aircraft, vessel, ship or boat while its power source is in operation.
No person may transfer any dangerous goods to any aircraft unless the aircraft is earthed to the transferral device by means of an earth cable.
The Chief Fire Officer must keep updated records of all vehicles in respect of which a transport permit has been issued, amended or renewed.

blockList.listIntroduction: No person may spray, coat, plate or epoxy-coat any vehicle, article, object or building or part thereof or allow them to be sprayed, coated, plated or epoxycoated with any flammable substance unless

item.p: that person is in possession of a spraying permit contemplated in section 80;
the spraying, coating, plating or epoxy-coating as the case may be is conducted in a spraying room approved by the Chief Fire Officer on premises registered for that purpose.

blockList.listIntroduction: Any person who wishes to obtain a spraying permit must

item.p: complete and submit to the Chief Fire Officer an application form for such permit in the form and manner determined by the Council; and
pay the prescribed fee.

blockList.listIntroduction: The provisions of section 24, read with the necessary changes, apply to the cancellation by the Chief Fire Officer of any spraying permit. Duties of owner, occupier or person in charge of spraying room 82. Every owner, occupier and person in charge of a spraying room must ensure that –

item.p: the spraying room complies with the requirements of this Chapter; and
every other person on the premises complies with the provisions of this Chapter.

section.heading: Design and construction of spraying rooms

blockList.listIntroduction: Every spraying room must be designed and constructed according to the following criteria:
every window frame must consist of steel with window panels -

item.p: that cannot be opened;
that do not exceed 450 millimetres x 450 millimetres in size; and
that are fitted with wire glass with a thickness not less than 8 millimetres;

blockList.listIntroduction: if based on a brick and concrete construction -

item.p: the floor must consist of concrete;
the walls must consist of brick or concrete;
the roof must consist of reinforced concrete; and
every door must consist of a Class B-type fire doors as contemplated in SABS 1253; and

blockList.listIntroduction: if based on a metal structure –

item.p: the framework of the structure, including door assemblies must consist of a sturdy steel profile with a minimum wall thickness of 2.5 millimetres;
the framework of the entire structure, including any door, must be clad on both sides with sheet metal with a minimum thickness of 1.3 millimetres;
the framework of the entire structure must be fume-proof, flameproof and liquid-proof;
the floor must consist of concrete or metal;
all material used must have a fire integrity grading of at least 60 minutes; and
the structure must be constructed, installed and finished so that all surfaces are smooth in order to prevent any furring which may hamper ventilation, washing or cleaning of the spraying room.

blockList.listIntroduction: Every spraying room which is designed and constructed with a sunken water floor must be designed and constructed so that -

item.p: the water is covered at the level of the sill by a sturdy, stable, noncombustible and corrosion-free floor grill capable of bearing the weight of every person and object in the spraying room; and

the water in the sunken water floor is circulated through an effective noncombustible and cleanable filtering system by a closed circuit pump circulation system consisting of non-corrosive metal pipes of suitable diameter and wall thickness.

content.p: Any electrical apparatus, light, fitting and switch gear installed or used in a spraying room must be installed and used in accordance with SABS 0108.

blockList.listIntroduction: Any switch gear, distribution boxe, fuse and other electrical equipment, except equipment as contemplated in SABS 0108 must -

item.p: be located outside the spraying room; and
be positioned so as not to come into contact with fumes from the spraying room.

content.p: Any switch for the mechanical ventilation system of a spraying room must be situated outside the spraying room.
Any metal part and electrical fitting and any other device used in, or in connection with, the spraying room, must be earthed effectively with each other and the ground.

blockList.listIntroduction: Every electrical installation in a spraying room may be installed only by a suitably qualified electrician who must -

item.p: certify in writing that the installation complies with all applicable legal requirements; and
furnish the certificate to the owner or person responsible for the premises concerned.

content.p: The owner or person responsible for the premises on which the spraying room is located must submit the certificate contemplated in subsection (5) to the Chief Fire Officer without delay.

blockList.listIntroduction: The owner, occupier and person in charge of a spraying room must ensure that there is an escape opening between the spraying room and any other activity, process or area on the premises concerned -

item.p: of at least 1200 millimetres wide; and
that must at all times be kept free of any obstruction, refuse or combustible material.

blockList.listIntroduction: If any other activity or process which may pose a fire hazard is conducted adjacent to a spraying room on any premises, the escape opening contemplated in subsection (1), must be clearly identified by a fire partition wall –

item.p: of a height at least 300 millimetres higher than the roof of the spraying room; and
with a fire resistance of at least 60 minutes.

content.p: No more than two sides of a spraying room contemplated in section 83(1)(c), may border a fire partition wall.

blockList.listIntroduction: In addition to any door for the access of motor vehicles or other objects to any spraying room, every spraying room must have at least two hinged doors for escape purposes that –

item.p: open to the outside of the spraying room;
have dimensions of at least 800 millimetres wide x 2000 millimetres high;
are positioned on opposite sides of the spraying room so that the distance to be covered to any door when any object is in the spraying room for spraying does not exceed 4 metres; and
are fitted with a locking mechanism that is at all times capable of being opened from the inside of the spraying room without the use of a key.

blockList.listIntroduction: Every spraying room must be equipped with a mechanical inlet and outlet ventilation system designed and installed -

item.p: so that ventilation of at least 0.5 metres per second is provided across the spraying room;
with vanes consisting of static-free material;
so that it releases fumes into the open air from outlets that are not located within 5 metres of any opening of a building or erf boundary;
with ventilators that are attached firmly to the inside walls of the spraying room with bottom ventilators affixed as close as possible to the level of the sill;
with ventilation and air duct openings installed in opposite walls, doors or the roof so as to ensure effective cross-ventilation; and

with ducting material that is fitted with a fire damper and covering of at least 120 minutes fire resistance where the ducting material exists the spraying room, if ducting material is installed external to the spraying room in communication with the remainder of the building concerned.

section.heading: Fire dampers, protectors and alarms in spraying rooms

content.p: A fire damper manufactured and installed in accordance with SABS 193, must be affixed in front of any air purification filter or part of such filter on the inside of any spraying room.

blockList.listIntroduction: The fire damper must –

item.p: be capable of closing automatically by means of a suitably located sensor that is activated by a rise of more than 10°C in the predetermined working temperature inside the spraying room;
be installed so that it will remain in position even if the air duct distorts during a fire; and
be equipped with an overriding fusible link.

blockList.listIntroduction: The ventilation system must be equipped with a sensor that -

item.p: is capable of turning off the ventilation system and any heating device used in connection with the spraying room, in the event of a fire or a rise of more than 10°C in the predetermined working temperature inside the spraying room; and
activates a visual and audible alarm inside and outside the spraying room in an event contemplated in paragraph (a).

section.heading: Design and positioning of ventilation outlets for spraying rooms

blockList.listIntroduction: Every outlet opening from a spraying room must be designed and positioned to release fumes from the spraying room into the open air at least -

item.p: 1 metre above any roof on the premises;
4 metres above the ground level; and
5 metres from any opening of a building situated on or adjacent to the spraying room.

section.heading: Display of signs on spraying rooms

content.p: A symbolic sign prohibiting open flames and smoking must be affixed to the inside and the outside of every door of a spraying room.

blockList.listIntroduction: Any symbolic sign contemplated in subsection (1), must be –

item.p: manufactured and installed in accordance with SABS 1186; and
of dimensions at least 290 millimetres by 290 millimetres.

blockList.listIntroduction: Every manifold installation of a Group II hazardous substance that forms an integral part of the heating system of any spraying room must -

item.p: comply with SABS 087 (Part 1); and
the requirements of these By-laws.

blockList.listIntroduction: No person may –

item.p: use any spraying room or allow any spraying room to be used unless signs prohibiting open flames and smoking are affixed to the spraying room in compliance with section 91;
enter a spraying room or allow any other person to enter a spraying room without the authority of the owner, occupier or person in control of the spraying room;
use any spraying room or allow any spraying room to be used for any purpose other than spray painting or related activities;
enter any spraying room or allow any other person to enter a spraying room unless the mechanical ventilation system is operating; or
place any obstruction of hindrance or allow any obstruction or hindrance to be placed in any escape opening or in front of any door of a spraying room.

section.heading: Fire extinguishing equipment in spraying rooms

blockList.listIntroduction: Every spraying room must be equipped with -

item.p: at least one 9 kilogram dry chemical fire extinguisher installed on the inside of the spraying room; and
at least one 9 kilogram dry chemical fire extinguisher installed on the outside of the spraying room.

content.p: Fire extinguishers contemplated in subsection (1) must be installed in positions approved by a member of the Service.

blockList.listIntroduction: Every spraying room must be protected by at least one fire hose reel as specified in SABS 543 -

item.p: that is connected to a water supply as contemplated in SABS 0400 (Part W); and
that enables the hose reel to maintain a flow of at least 0.5 litres per second at a work pressure of at least 300 kPa.

content.p: The Council has established a Fire Brigade Service as contemplated in section 3 of the Fire Brigade Services Act.

blockList.listIntroduction: The Council must maintain the Service, which includes -

item.p: appointing a Chief Fire Officer and the necessary members of the Service;
ensuring that they are properly trained; and
acquiring and maintaining the necessary vehicles, machinery, equipment, devices and accessories to ensure that the Service is effective and able to fulfil its objects.

blockList.listIntroduction: The objects of the Service are –

item.p: to prevent the outbreak and spread of fire;
to fight and extinguish any fire that endangers any person or property;
to protect any person and property against any fire hazard or other danger contemplated in these By-laws; and
to rescue any person and property from any fire or other danger contemplated in these By-laws.

content.p: The Service may, provide any service related to its objects to any other person against payment of the prescribed fee.
Any service contemplated in subsection (1), may be terminated without notice if the services, equipment or personnel involved in providing that service are required to deal with an emergency.

In addition to any powers under section 8 of the Fire Brigade Services Act, a member may give any instruction to any person in order to secure compliance with these By-laws or to ensure the safety of any person or property.
An instruction may be given orally or in writing and if the instruction is given orally, the member must confirm it in writing and give it to the person concerned at the earliest opportunity.

blockList.listIntroduction: An instruction contemplated in subsection (1) may include, but is not limited to an instruction -

item.p: for the immediate evacuation of any premises;
to close any premises until such time as any contravention of these By-laws has been rectified;
to cease any activity;
to remove any immediate threat to the safety of any person or property;
to take specified steps to comply with these By-laws, either immediately or within a specified period; and

if it is not reasonable for steps referred to in paragraph (e), to be taken immediately, for the owner or occupier of the premises concerned to provide the Chief Fire Officer with a written description of the steps to be taken and a time-table for the taking of these steps in order to ensure compliance with these By-laws.

section.heading: Pretending to be member of service prohibited

content.p: No person may pretend to be a member.
No person who is not a member may wear any official clothing, uniform, badge or insignia of the Service.

section.heading: Certificates to identify members of service

content.p: The Chief Fire Officer must provide each member with a certificate identifying that person as a member.

blockList.listIntroduction: A member, while performing any function or exercising any power under these By-laws must –

item.p: keep the certificate provided in terms of subsection (1), on his or her person; and
produce it for inspection on request by any person.

content.p: Any costs incurred by the Council in connection with the analysis of any sample taken from any premises for the purposes of these By-laws, and a report on such analysis by an institution accredited by the Chief Fire Officer for that purpose may be recovered from the owner or occupier of that premises if the owner or occupier of the premises is not in compliance with these By-laws regarding the substance concerned.

The owner, occupier or person in charge of any zoological garden, feedlot, stable, research institution, veterinary practice or any place of veterinary science study, must ensure the professional handling of any animal on the premises concerned during an emergency.
Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (1), the Chief Fire Officer may, in respect of any premises, authorise a suitably qualified person to handle or put down any animal during an emergency.
The Council may recover any costs incurred in relation to the professional handling or putting down of any animal during an emergency from the owner or occupier of the premises concerned.

section.heading: Exemption from provisions of these by-laws

content.p: Any person may make application to the Council in writing, for an exemption from any provision of these By-laws, specifying the reasons for exemption in such application.

blockList.listIntroduction: The Council may grant an exemption –

item.p: in general or in particular;
for any period; and
subject to any condition that will provide the same overall fire prevention and protection that would result from the full application of these By-laws.

content.p: If an exemption is granted in terms of subsection (2), the Council must issue a certificate of exemption to the person concerned, specifying the scope and period of the exemption and any condition imposed.
The Council may amend or withdraw a certificate of exemption at any time.
The holder of a certificate of exemption must ensure that the certificate is available on the premises concerned at all times for inspection by any member.

section.heading: Approval, authorisation or permission under these by-laws

blockList.listIntroduction: Any person who requires any approval, authorisation or permission contemplated in these By-laws, in respect of which no application procedure is provided, must apply for that approval, authorisation or permission -

item.p: by completing and submitting an application in the form and manner determined by the Council; and
by paying the prescribed fee.

section.heading: Cancellation of approval, authorisation or permission

content.p: The provisions of section 24, read with the necessary changes, apply to any approval, authorisation or permission contemplated in section 104.
These By-laws bind the State and any person in the service of the State.

blockList.listIntroduction: Any person who –

item.p: contravenes or fails to comply with any provision of these by-laws;
fails to comply with any notice issued or displayed in terms of these By-laws;
fails to comply with any lawful instruction given in terms of these By-laws; or

obstructs or hinders, or imporoperly influences or attempts to do so, any authorised representative or employee of the Council in the execution of his or her duties or performance of his or her powers or functions under these By-laws;

content.p: is guilty of an offence and liable on conviction to a fine or in default of payment to imprisonment for a period not exceeding six months, and in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine not exceeding R50, or in default of payment, to imprisonment not exceeding one day, for every day during the continuance of such offence, after a written notice has been issued by the Council, and served on the person concerned, requesting the discontinuance of such offence.
The by-laws listed in Schedule 5 are hereby repealed.
These By-laws are called the Emergency Services By-Laws, 2003.
Every emergency evacuation plan contemplated in section 17 must contain at least the information under the headings below.
Emergency telephone numbers
A list of all relevant emergency telephone numbers.

blockList.listIntroduction: General information

item.p: the physical address of the premises;
a description of the activities on the premises;
the number of persons present on the premises at any time;
an indication of any control room on the premises;
an indication of any alarm system on the premises; and
the particulars and contact details of every responsible person in the event of an emergency;

content.p: Area study

blockList.listIntroduction: An area study addressing the following:

item.p: a history of emergency incidents on the premises;
any important and relevant features or landmarks regarding the premises; and
any information regarding adjacent premises that may be relevant to evacuation in an emergency.

content.p: Socio-economic or other threats
Any socio-economic or other threats and their potential impact on the premises.
Details of available equipment

blockList.listIntroduction: Particulars and details regarding the position of the following equipment:

item.p: Equipment in the control room;
fire fighting and first aid equipment on the premises; and
any other equipment which may be relevant in an emergency.

content.p: The emergency team

blockList.listIntroduction: Particulars and details regarding the identity of members of the emergency team, including -

item.p: its management;
the continuity officers;
the fire teams; and
the first aid teams.

content.p: Duties of emergency team members
The duties and responsibilities of members of the emergency team.
Action plans and emergency procedures
Details of the specific action plans and emergency procedures applicable to the premises.
Building plans and maps
The building plans of the premises and any relevant topographical map must be included in the evacuation plan.

blockList.listIntroduction: Emergency plan register The plan must include –

item.p: an updated register of the emergency evacuation plan;
an updated drill register for the emergency evacuation plan; and
a bomb threat questionnaire.

content.p: An emergency evacuation plan must be reviewed and updated by the owner or occupier of the premises concerned at least once each year and whenever a member of the management of the emergency team ceases to work at the premises.

Whenever an emergency evacuation plan is reviewed and updated, the owner or occupier of the premises concerned must ensure that all old plans on the premises or in the possession of the management of the emergency team are collected and destroyed in order to eliminate any confusion regarding the validity and accuracy of the evacuation plan.
An emergency evacuation plan should be drilled at least twice each year and involve the participation of all persons who work or reside in the building concerned.
The owner or person in charge of a building should give all persons who are to be involved in an emergency evacuation drill at least 21 days’ notice of the drill.
Every person who works or resides on premises should be aware of the emergency evacuation plan for that premises.

blockList.listIntroduction: Every person who resides or works on premises with an emergency evacuation plan should be suitably trained in -

item.p: first aid or fire fighting;
emergency aid;
emergency evacuation procedures; and
emergency management techniques.
